awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Scaling Design Critique Through Novel Interactive Systems for In-Class Peer Feedback
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) program, this project will investigate how digital, in-class peer feedback systems can improve project-based learning in technical fields.  It will also investigate how such feedback systems scale to various class sizes. This project focuses on the growing need to train American workers for jobs that need problem-solving abilities. It also addresses the need to actively engage students who avoid participation, due to social barriers such as discomfort with public speaking. Effective feedback is an important part of project-based learning. This award will support feedback activities in the classroom, where students can learn from the shared environment. In the feedback system being used, both the author and the reviewers are anonymous.  This feature may mitigate social barriers to participation and promote unbiased evaluation. This project aims to enhance an existing web-based, in-class peer feedback system.  Specifically, it plans add functionality to enable the author of a project to ?review the reviewer,? i.e. to provide the reviewer with feedback about the quality or usefulness of the review. Initial studies will occur at Carnegie Mellon University and the University of California San Diego. 

The goal of this project is to explore several unanswered questions about in-class peer feedback: how to improve the quality of in-class peer feedback using reflection activities; how to increase engagement with the peer feedback process using social factors such as emotional expressiveness and a sense of connection to peers;  how data logs generated by a digital feedback application (PeerPresents) can help instructors with assessment and with implementing new class activities or pedagogies; and how in-class peer feedback might work differently in classes of different size. PeerPresents will be used as a platform to develop interventions, and to study student engagement in and the effectiveness of reciprocal peer feedback. Activities include deploying the system in classrooms, interviewing students and instructors, evaluating the quality of feedback provided, and analyzing system logs. The work has the potential to inform the design of future peer feedback systems, as well as to improve peer feedback practices within college classrooms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project-based learning helps students master complicated design processes, like game design or creating new software. It relies on having frequent, high-quality feedback on student work in progress - but instructors often struggle to provide enough feedback, particularly as classes get large. Peer feedback exchange, where students give feedback to one another, can help students learn while reducing the burden on instructors.

We developed a web-based system, PeerPresents, to facilitate peer feedback exchange. We learned that contrary to instructor expectations, digital peer feedback does not lower feedback quality or distract students. We tested new methods for helping peers give and get better feedback, such as helping designers ask better questions of their peers and giving design teams effective tools for reflecting on the feedback they received.

We found that teams generated better questions for their peers when they did so collaboratively, and that questions framed as asking for "improvements" elicited the highest quality feedback from fellow students. We identified common problems with teams' initial analysis of peer feedback, like valuing long comments over high-quality comments. To help teams make better use of feedback, we designed a system that combined simple technical features (e.g. individual rating of comments on a scale from 1 to 5) and intelligent team prompts (e.g. asking teams to pay attention to comments where team members disagreed, rather than comments where all team members agreed it was valuable). 

To make our system usable by instructors, we studied what instructors needed from a real-time peer feedback system. We used this to design instructor dashboards, that would help instructors improve their teaching and use peer feedback effectively. For example, instructors often wanted to flag high-quality feedback so that other students could improve their own feedback quality. We provided dashboards and interfaces for instructors to help with these kinds of activities.

We have been able to deploy our system in many different design classrooms, including game design, software design, and service design. We have tested our system to make sure it is stable, scalable, and secure. We hope that instructors using project-based learning will use our system!
